content: The "Hong Kong Reversion Act" aims to support Hong Kong's autonomous governance and the well-being of its people by ensuring the continuity of US laws after its reversion to China in 1997. It also outlines circumstances for the US President to modify laws if China fails to uphold Hong Kong's autonomy. The Joint Declaration of the UK and China on Hong Kong in 1984 is a binding agreement for the reversion of Hong Kong to China in 1997, ensuring a high degree of autonomy and basic human rights. Despite assurances from senior Chinese officials for a smooth transfer of Hong Kong to Chinese sovereignty and respect for the "one country, two systems" policy, there have been attempts to infringe upon Hong Kong's autonomy, including proposals to obtain confidential files on civil servants. The curr_chunk discusses various concerning actions by the Government of the People's Republic of China regarding Hong Kong, including dissolving the Legislative Council, restricting speech and association, warning religious institutions, and appointing a provisional legislature. The Standing Committee of the National People's Congress of China decided on February 23, 1997, to repeal or amend certain Hong Kong ordinances, including the Bill of Rights Ordinance, Societies Ordinance of 1992, and Public Order Ordinance of 1995. Despite commitments in the Joint Declaration, UK's actions have damaged Hong Kong's autonomy, such as the agreement on the Court of Final Appeal. The reversion of Hong Kong to China has implications for US national interests and the rights of Hong Kong people. The US has a responsibility to protect its interests during this transition and ensure the human rights of Hong Kong residents are upheld. The US-Hong Kong Policy Act of 1992 is relevant in this context. The United States-Hong Kong Policy Act of 1992 ensures the continuity of US laws regarding Hong Kong's special status as a Special Administrative Region of China. It allows the President to modify the application of US laws if Hong Kong is not sufficiently autonomous. The United States-Hong Kong Policy Act of 1992 aims to maintain Hong Kong's autonomy by treating it as a separate legal entity from China, as long as China agrees to grant Hong Kong a high degree of autonomy. The Act also requires the Secretary of State to assess the implementation of the Joint Declaration. The future of Hong Kong depends on China's commitment to uphold the freedoms and self-governance outlined in the Joint Declaration. SEC. 4. CONGRESSIONAL DECLARATIONS. Congress declares the close working relationship between the US and Hong Kong governments, urging continued cooperation. The US also emphasizes the importance of preserving Hong Kong's autonomous customs territory and calls on China to respect its autonomy. The United States urges China to respect Hong Kong's autonomy, including its customs territory and free press rights. The United States calls for elections in Hong Kong to be conducted according to laws approved by the people or their representatives, in line with the Joint Declaration. Failure to have an elected legislature would violate the treaty obligations, and China is urged to honor its commitments. The United States supports the Bill of Rights Ordinance in Hong Kong and calls for democratic control over revisions to Hong Kong law. It also urges China to uphold its commitments under the Joint Declaration and the International Covenant on Human Rights. The United States supports the Bill of Rights Ordinance in Hong Kong and urges democratic control over legislative revisions, emphasizing adherence to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. The United States urges China to respect the autonomy of Hong Kong's government institutions and fight against corruption. The United States urges China to respect Hong Kong's autonomy and fight corruption. Presidential determination under the United States-Hong Kong Policy Act of 1992 and additional reporting requirements are outlined in Section 5. The President will assess Hong Kong's autonomy under US laws, considering the Hong Kong Government's performance and China's actions. The Secretary of State must include specific information in reports to Congress as required by the United States-Hong Kong Policy Act of 1992. The Secretary will assess whether Hong Kong has a freely elected legislature and if agreements are concluded successfully and timely. The United States Government has cooperated with the People's Republic of China in securing various agreements and treaties, including a bilateral investment treaty, an extradition treaty, an agreement on consular access in Hong Kong for US citizens, a preservation agreement for the US consulate, a mutual legal assistance agreement, a prison transfer agreement, and a civil aviation agreement. This cooperation is ongoing. The Secretary assesses the cooperation of Hong Kong government agencies with the United States in customs enforcement, drug interdiction, and anti-money laundering efforts. Additionally, the Secretary evaluates the autonomy, lack of corruption, and respect for the rule of law in Hong Kong. Any attempts to undermine the Bill of Rights in Hong Kong are also noted in the report. The Secretary assesses violations of laws, interference in autonomy, corruption, and suppression of press freedom in Hong Kong. The report also evaluates the autonomy of the customs territory of Hong Kong. The Secretary's report highlights violations of United States textile laws, export control laws, and high technology export diversions from Hong Kong. It also mentions unprecedented Chinese exports diversion through Hong Kong for preferential treatment in US markets and misuse of Hong Kong's customs territory for China's foreign policy or trade goals. SEC. 6 prohibits the use of funds from the United States Information Agency for any member of the Hong Kong provisional legislature to participate in certain programs. The term "Hong Kong provisional legislature" refers to the body appointed in 1996 to replace the elected Hong Kong Legislative Council. SEC. 7 defines the term "Joint Declaration" as the agreement between the UK and China on Hong Kong signed in 1984.
